{{coord|38|59|15.0|N|76|56|24.0|W|region:US-MD_type:edu|display=title}} {{Infobox University |name = College of Behavioral and Social Sciences |image = |established = 1919 |type = [[Public university|Public]] |dean = Gregory Ball |city = Tydings Hall, [[College Park, Maryland|College Park]] |state = [[Maryland]] |country = United States |campus = [[Suburb]]an |nickname = BSOS |website = http://www.bsos.umd.edu/ }} '''The University of Maryland College of Behavioral and Social Sciences''' is one of the 13 schools and colleges at the [[University of Maryland, College Park]]. With 10 departments, it is one of the largest colleges at the university, with three in ten University of Maryland undergraduates receiving their degree from the college.{{cite web|url=http://www.bsos.umd.edu/about-us/a-message-from-the-dean.aspx |title=College of Behavioral and Social Sciences - A Message from the Dean |publisher=Bsos.umd.edu |date= |accessdate=2011-08-17}} 45 research centers also are located in the College.[http://www.bsos.umd.edu/media/35897/strategic%20plan%202009.pdf] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100604044400/http://www.bsos.umd.edu/media/35897/strategic%20plan%202009.pdf |date=June 4, 2010 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.bsos.umd.edu/academics--research/centers.aspx |title=College of Behavioral and Social Sciences - Centers |publisher=Bsos.umd.edu |date= |accessdate=2011-08-17}} Its [[social science]] programs are collectively ranked 10th in the United States by the [[Faculty Scholarly Productivity Index]], and 18th in the world by the Institute of Higher Education at [[Academic Ranking of World Universities|Shanghai Jiao Tong University]].[http://www.bsos.umd.edu/about-us/facts--stats.aspx ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100612060351/http://www.bsos.umd.edu/about-us/facts--stats.aspx |date=June 12, 2010 }} ==History== [[File:UMD Tydings North.JPG|thumb|right| North view of Millard E. Tydings Hall, home to the College of Behavioral and Social Sciences as well as the Department of Economics and the Department Government & Politics]] [[File:UMD Tydings South.JPG|thumb|right|South view of Tydings Hall]] The College of Behavioral and Social Sciences began as "The School of Liberal Arts" in 1919, and was headquartered in [[Morrill Hall (University of Maryland)|Morrill Hall]]; Frederic E. Lee served as the school's first dean. In the 1920s, it became "The College of Arts and Sciences," with five separate divisions. In 1936, the college moved into the newly completed College of Arts and Sciences Building, which was renamed Francis Scott Key Hall in 1955. In the 1940s, the departments of Economics, Geography and Government & Politics moved into The College of Business and Public Administration.{{cite web|url=http://www.bsos.umd.edu/about-us/history.aspx |title=College of Behavioral and Social Sciences - History |publisher=Bsos.umd.edu |date= |accessdate=2011-08-17}} In 1972, the College of Arts and Sciences and the College of Business and Public Administration combined to become the new "Division of Behavioral and Social Sciences", one of five divisions in the university. In 1986, the five divisions split into fourteen colleges, and The College of Behavioral and Social Sciences was formed. The college has been headquartered in Millard E. Tydings Hall since 1993. ==Departments== {| class=wikitable |- ! |publisher=Grad-schools.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com |date= |accessdate=2011-08-17}} |} ==Undergraduate opportunities== ===CIVICUS=== {{Original research|section|date=December 2013}}CIVICUS is a two-year living and learning undergraduate program in the College of Behavioral and Social Sciences, which links academic coursework together with participation in internships and community service to provide an experience of civil service engagement for participants (known as CIVICUS Associates). CIVICUS Associates live together in Somerset Hall (located in the North Hill Community), which was renovated in 1999 for the CIVICUS Living and Learning Program. Somerset Hall also houses the program's offices and hosts CIVICUS classes. The hall is designed with several study and social lounges to enhance students' living and learning experience. Somerset is located centrally on campus making the walk to classes, the dining hall, McKeldin Library, and the Stamp Student Union quick and convenient. All the rooms in Somerset are air conditioned and each student has his/her own internet, phone, and cable jack. Most of the rooms are doubles with a few triples and quads scattered throughout the building. There are also some singles. In addition, there is a computer lab and laundry facility located on the ground floor. Each floor also has one or two small kitchenettes with a microwave and a sink.http://www.civicus.umd.edu/somerset.htm For students entering CIVICUS in the fall of their freshman year, the CIVICUS classes students are required to take in their first semester consist of a 1-credit class called CIVICUS Student and the University (BSCV181) and a 3-credit class called Introduction to CIVICUS (BSCV191). In their second semester, students take a 1-credit class called CIVICUS and Service Learning (BSCV182) and a 3 credit class called Introduction to Contemporary Social Problems (SOCY105). In their third semester in the CIVICUS program, students take a 3-credit class called Leadership in a Multicultural Society. In the last semester in the program students take the CIVICUS Capstone 3 credit class (BSCV302) that gives them academic credit for their CIVICUS Internship. A student can take a 1 credit class instead if the student is getting academic credit from another academic program. The creator and current director of the program is Dr. Sue Briggs, who teaches the majority of the required courses, as well as provides assistance and information regarding all aspects of the program. In addition to the in-class requirements, CIVICUS associates are responsible for completing four service projects per semester, a long term service project, and an internship.[http://www.civicus.umd.edu/somerset.htm CIVIUS Website, Somerset Hall] Retrieved 2010-7-8 Associates also participate in an additional two community days of service, once per semester. Students are able to participate in wide variety of service activities, ranging from those on campus, to those in the surrounding counties and Washington, D.C. The program is based on the five principles of civil society: citizenship, leadership, community building in a diverse society, scholarship, and community service-learning. CIVICUS is a program for enthusiastic, motivated, and dedicated students who want to get involved with the campus and local community to make a positive difference. CIVICUS comprises a diverse group of student leaders whose distinct personalities, perspectives, and backgrounds enrich class discussions, service projects, and the conversations throughout the halls of Somerset. This camaraderie continues even after CIVICUS students have completed their citation, as many CIVICUS juniors and seniors return regularly to Somerset and remain involved with the program. In addition to being involved with the CIVICUS community, many of the students are actively involved in the university and local communities.http://www.civicus.umd.edu/associates.htm University of Maryland freshmen applicants whose application materials suggest they possess significant levels of leadership, involvement, and motivation are invited to join the program.[http://www.civicus.umd.edu/faq.htm#1 CIVICUS Website, FAQ] Retrieved 2010-7-8 A total of 130 associates are in the program at a time.{{cite web | last = University of Maryland | title = CIVICUS Living and Learning Program | accessdate = 2010-07-08 | date = 2009-12-15 | url = http://www.civicus.umd.edu/home.htm }} ===Mock Trial team=== The University of Maryland Mock Trial Team is a student organization which engages in [[Mock Trial#College|intercollegiate mock trial competition]]. Based out of the Department of Government and Politics in the College of Behavioral and Social Sciences, the team first began competing in 1990.[http://www.newsdesk.umd.edu/undergradexp/release.cfm?ArticleID=1629 UM Newsdesk. The 'Other' March Madness: UM Wins National Mock Trial. April 7, 2008.] Retrieved 2010-7-8. The Maryland team has won [[Mock Trial#Past championship results|five national championships]] (2008, 2000, 1998, 1996, 1992), which ranks the most of any university, and was also the national runner-up in 1992 and 1993. ==Faculty== There are two [[Endowed professorship|endowed chairs]] within the College of Behavioral and Social Sciences: the ''Anwar Sadat Chair for Peace and Development'', currently held by [[Shibley Telhami]], and the ''Bahá'í Chair for World Peace'', currently held by John Grayzel, are at the Center for International Development and Conflict Management, which is a center within the Department of Government and Politics.{{cite web|url=http://www.bsos.umd.edu/academics--research/special-college-programs.aspx |title=College of Behavioral and Social Sciences - Special College Programs |publisher=Bsos.umd.edu |date= |accessdate=2011-08-17}} Notable faculty in the College include: *[[Gar Alperovitz]] (Department of Government and Politics) *[[Charles Butterworth (philosopher)|Charles Butterworth]] (Department of Government and Politics) *[[Patricia Hill Collins]] (Department of Sociology) *[[Ruth DeFries]] (Department of Geography), member of the [[United States National Academy of Sciences|National Academy of Sciences]] and [[MacArthur Fellow]] *[[Ted Robert Gurr]] (Department of Government and Politics) *[[Mark P. Leone]] (Department of Anthropology) *[[George Ritzer]] (Department of Sociology) *[[Jehan Al Sadat]] (Center for International Development and Conflict Management) *[[Thomas Schelling]] (Department of Economics), winner of the [[Nobel Prize in Economics]]{{cite web |url=http://www.econ.umd.edu/faculty/profiles/schelling |title=Department of Economics, University of Maryland |publisher=Econ.umd.edu |date=2009-01-22 |accessdate=2011-08-17 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110818230601/http://www.econ.umd.edu/faculty/profiles/schelling |archive-date=2011-08-18 |dead-url=yes |df= }} and member of the [[United States National Academy of Sciences|National Academy of Sciences]] *[[Shibley Telhami]] (Department of Government and Politics) *[[Vladimir Tismăneanu]] (Department of Government and Politics) Notable former faculty members include: *[[Oliver Edwin Baker]] (Department of Geography) *[[John W. Dorsey]] (Department of Economics) *[[Parris Glendening]] (Department of Government and Politics) *[[Edward B. Montgomery]] (Department of Economics) *[[Mancur Olson]] (Department of Economics) *[[Carmen Reinhart]] (Department of Economics) *[[John W. Snow]] (Department of Economics) *[[Ron Walters]] (Department of Government and Politics) ==Notable alumni==

Other prominent alumni include:[[Eric F. Billings]], [[Chairman]] and [[Chief Executive Officer]] of [[FBR Capital Markets Corporation]]; [[John Dryzek]], social and political theorist; [[Robert W. Jordan]], former [[United States Ambassadors to Saudi Arabia|U.S. Ambassador to Saudi Arabia]]; [[Kori Schake]], former director for Defense Strategy and Requirements on the [[United States National Security Council|National Security Council]]; [[Charles Schultze]], former [[Chairman]] of the United States [[Council of Economic Advisers]]; and [[Torrey Smith]], an [[NFL]] wide receiver currently playing with the [[Philadelphia Eagles]]. ==See also== *[[Center for American Politics and Citizenship]] *[[List of Sadat Lecture for Peace Speakers]] *[[Minorities at Risk]] ==Notes== {{Reflist|group=n}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.bsos.umd.edu/ BSOS Website] *[http://www.civicus.umd.edu/home.htm CIVICUS Website] *[http://www.peace.umd.edu Pathways to Peace at the University of Maryland] {{University of Maryland, College Park}} {{DEFAULTSORT:University Of Maryland College Of Behavioral And Social Sciences}} [[Category:University of Maryland College of Behavioral and Social Sciences| ]] [[Category:University of Maryland, College Park facilities|Behavioral and Social Sciences]] [[Category:Liberal arts colleges at universities in the United States]] [[Category:University subdivisions in Maryland|Behavioral and Social Sciences]] [[Category:Psychology departments in the United States]] [[Category:Social sciences organizations]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1919]]

{{Infobox person | name = V. P. Balagangadharan | image = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1950|01|20}} | birth_place = [[Payyanur]], [[Kerala]], India | nationality = Indian | education = [[Master of Science]] in [[Chemistry]] | alma_mater = [[University of Kerala]], [[Savitribai Phule Pune University]] | organization = [[Indian Space Research Organization]] | years_active = 1971–present | awards = Kerala Science Literature Award, 2015 }} '''Vannadil Puthiyaveettil "V. P." Balagangadharan''' (born 20 January 1950) is a space scientist, author, and speaker from [[India]], known for his contributions to propellant research,<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.kas.org.in/index.php/membership/fellows|title=Fellows|last=User|first=Super|website=www.kas.org.in|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-09-09}}</ref> technology transfer,<ref name="Workshop on IPR at Cusat">{{Cite news|url=https://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-kerala/Workshop-on-IPR-at-Cusat/article14707375.ece|title=Workshop on IPR at Cusat|date=2007-01-17|work=The Hindu|access-date=2018-09-09|language=en-IN|issn=0971-751X}}</ref> and science communication. He has worked with the [[Indian Space Research Organisation]] for over four decades in various roles.
== Education == After finishing his schooling at AV Smaraka Govt. Higher Secondary School, [[Karivellur]], and [[Pre-Degree course|Pre-Degree]] from [[Payyanur College]], Balagangadharan joined [[Malabar Christian College]], [[Kozhikode]] in 1967, from where he completed his [[Bachelor of Science]] in [[Chemistry]] in 1970. While working at [[Vikram Sarabhai Space Centre]], he completed his [[Master of Science]] in [[Chemistry]] from [[Savitribai Phule Pune University|Pune University]] in 1989.
== Career == Balagangadharan started his career as an Analytical Chemist at [[Bombay Oil Industries]], [[Angamaly]] in 1971. In 1972, he joined [[Vikram Sarabhai Space Centre]] as a Scientific Assistant in its Propellant Engineering Division, later Analytical & Spectroscopy Division. After almost four decades of service, in 2010, he superannuated as the Group Head, Technology Transfer and Documentation Division at the centre. Post superannuation, he held the emeritus role as Prof. [[Brahm Prakash]] Scientist<ref>http://www.patentcentre.kerala.gov.in/pdf/bulletin_third.pdf</ref>—two stints, separated by a one year role as Consultant and Advisor (Media & Communications)—till 2014<ref name=":0" />
He was formerly the Chairman<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/Thiruvananthapuram/kscste-recasts-advisory-panel-on-ipr/article7060633.ece|title=KSCSTE recasts advisory panel on IPR|date=2015-04-02|work=The Hindu|access-date=2018-09-09|others=Special Correspondent|language=en-IN|issn=0971-751X}}</ref> of the Patent Advisory Committee of the [[Government of Kerala]].
== Science communication == He has over 30<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://scholar.google.co.in/scholar?hl=en&as_sdt=0,5&q=VP+Balagangadharan&btnG=&oq=balag|title=Google Scholar|website=scholar.google.co.in|access-date=2018-09-09}}</ref> research publications<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/scientific-contributions/83957644_V_P_Balagangadharan|title=V. P. Balagangadharan's research works {{!}} Vikram Sarabhai Space Centre, Thiruvananthapuram and other places|website=ResearchGate|language=en|access-date=2018-09-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=36LfBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA595&lpg=PA595&dq=balagangadharan+vp#v=onepage&q=balagangadharan%20vp&f=false|title=Frontiers of Polymer Research|last=Nigam|first=Jai K.|last2=Prasad|first2=Paras N.|date=2012-12-06|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|isbn=9781461538561|language=en}}</ref><ref name="Ninan 1993 255–260">{{Cite journal|last=Ninan|first=K. N.|last2=Balagangadharan|first2=V. P.|last3=Ambikadevi|first3=K.|last4=Catherine|first4=K. B.|date=1993|title=Functionality distribution and crosslink density of hydroxyl-terminated polybutadiene|journal=Polymer International|language=en|volume=31|issue=3|pages=255–260|doi=10.1002/pi.4990310307|issn=0959-8103}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ninan|first=K.N.|last2=Balagangadharan|first2=V.P.|last3=Catherine|first3=Korah Bina|date=1991-01|title=Studies on the functionality distribution of hydroxyl-terminated polybutadiene and correlation with mechanical properties|url=https://www.mendeley.com/papers/studies-functionality-distribution-hydroxylterminated-polybutadiene-correlation-mechanical-propertie/|journal=Polymer|language=en-GB|volume=32|issue=4|pages=628–635|doi=10.1016/0032-3861(91)90474-W|issn=0032-3861}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Ninan|first1=K.N|last2=Balagangadharan|first2=V.P|last3=Ramasubramanian|first3=T.S|date=1986-01-01|title=Detection and determination of formaldehyde dimethylhydrazone in mixtures with 1,1-dimethylhydrazine|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0003267086800708|journal=Analytica Chimica Acta|language=en|volume=185|pages=377–380|doi=10.1016/0003-2670(86)80070-8|issn=0003-2670}}</ref><ref name="Ninan 1993 255–260"/><ref>{{Citation|last=Ninan|first=K.
